mn13:0.2.eng: The Longer Discourse on the Mass of Suffering

mn13:1.2.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā sāvatthiyaṃ viharati jetavane anāthapiṇḍikassa ārāme.
mn13:1.2.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.

mn13:2.1.pli: Atha kho sambahulā bhikkhū pubbaṇhasamayaṃ nivāsetvā pattacīvaramādāya sāvatthiṃ piṇḍāya pāvisiṃsu.
mn13:2.1.eng: Then several mendicants robed up in the morning and, taking their bowls and robes, entered Sāvatthī for alms.

mn13:2.3.eng: “It’s too early to wander for alms in Sāvatthī.

mn13:2.4.pli: yaṃ nūna mayaṃ yena aññatitthiyānaṃ paribbājakānaṃ ārāmo tenupasaṅkameyyāmā”ti.
mn13:2.4.eng: Why don’t we visit the monastery of the wanderers of other religions?”

mn13:2.5.pli: Atha kho te bhikkhū yena aññatitthiyānaṃ paribbājakānaṃ ārāmo tenupasaṅkamiṃsu; upasaṅkamitvā tehi aññatitthiyehi paribbājakehi saddhiṃ sammodiṃsu;
mn13:2.5.eng: Then they went to the monastery of the wanderers of other religions and exchanged greetings with the wanderers there.

mn13:2.6.pli: sammodanīyaṃ kathaṃ sāraṇīyaṃ vītisāretvā ekamantaṃ nisīdiṃsu. Ekamantaṃ nisinne kho te bhikkhū te aññatitthiyā paribbājakā etadavocuṃ:
mn13:2.6.eng: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, they sat down to one side. The wanderers said to them:

mn13:3.1.pli: “samaṇo, āvuso, gotamo kāmānaṃ pariññaṃ paññapeti, mayampi kāmānaṃ pariññaṃ paññapema;
mn13:3.1.eng: “Reverends, the ascetic Gotama advocates the complete understanding of sensual pleasures, and so do we.
mn13:3.1.comm: This group of three—kāma, rūpa, vedanā—is also found at AN 3.126 and AN 10.29, where it also relates to the teachings of outsiders.

mn13:3.2.pli: samaṇo, āvuso, gotamo rūpānaṃ pariññaṃ paññapeti, mayampi rūpānaṃ pariññaṃ paññapema;
mn13:3.2.eng: The ascetic Gotama advocates the complete understanding of forms, and so do we.

mn13:3.3.pli: samaṇo, āvuso, gotamo vedanānaṃ pariññaṃ paññapeti, mayampi vedanānaṃ pariññaṃ paññapema;
mn13:3.3.eng: The ascetic Gotama advocates the complete understanding of feelings, and so do we.
mn13:3.3.comm: The text does not say what the wanderers understood by these three full understandings. The commentary says they spoke in reference to, respectively, the first absorption, the formless attainments, and the non-percipient state.

mn13:3.4.pli: idha no, āvuso, ko viseso, ko adhippayāso, kiṃ nānākaraṇaṃ samaṇassa vā gotamassa amhākaṃ vā—
mn13:3.4.eng: What, then, is the difference between the ascetic Gotama’s teaching and instruction and ours?”
mn13:3.4.comm: In questioning this, the wanderers display better discernment than many today, who leap all too readily from the discovery of something in common between religions to the assertion that they are therefore the same.

mn13:3.5.pli: yadidaṃ dhammadesanāya vā dhammadesanaṃ, anusāsaniyā vā anusāsanin”ti?

mn13:4.1.pli: Atha kho te bhikkhū tesaṃ aññatitthiyānaṃ paribbājakānaṃ bhāsitaṃ neva abhinandiṃsu, nappaṭikkosiṃsu;
mn13:4.1.eng: Those mendicants neither approved nor rejected that statement of the wanderers of other religions.

mn13:4.2.eng: They got up from their seat, thinking,

mn13:4.3.eng: “We will learn the meaning of this statement from the Buddha himself.”
mn13:4.3.comm: This is the quintessential Buddhist attitude when encountering something unknown: to neither accept nor reject, but inquire.

mn13:5.1.pli: Atha kho te bhikkhū sāvatthiyaṃ piṇḍāya caritvā pacchābhattaṃ piṇḍapātapaṭikkantā yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkamiṃsu; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdiṃsu. Ekamantaṃ nisinnā kho te bhikkhū bhagavantaṃ etadavocuṃ:
mn13:5.1.eng: Then, after the meal, when they returned from almsround, they went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and told him what had happened. The Buddha said:

mn13:5.2.pli: “idha mayaṃ, bhante, pubbaṇhasamayaṃ nivāsetvā pattacīvaramādāya sāvatthiṃ piṇḍāya pāvisimha.

mn13:5.5.pli: yaṃ nūna mayaṃ yena aññatitthiyānaṃ paribbājakānaṃ ārāmo tenupasaṅkameyyāmā’ti.

mn13:5.6.pli: Atha kho mayaṃ, bhante, yena aññatitthiyānaṃ paribbājakānaṃ ārāmo tenupasaṅkamimha; upasaṅkamitvā tehi aññatitthiyehi paribbājakehi saddhiṃ sammodimha;

mn13:5.7.pli: sammodanīyaṃ kathaṃ sāraṇīyaṃ vītisāretvā ekamantaṃ nisīdimha. Ekamantaṃ nisinne kho amhe, bhante, te aññatitthiyā paribbājakā etadavocuṃ:

mn13:5.8.pli: ‘samaṇo, āvuso, gotamo kāmānaṃ pariññaṃ paññapeti, mayampi kāmānaṃ pariññaṃ paññapema.

mn13:5.9.pli: Samaṇo, āvuso, gotamo rūpānaṃ pariññaṃ paññapeti, mayampi rūpānaṃ pariññaṃ paññapema.

mn13:5.10.pli: Samaṇo, āvuso, gotamo vedanānaṃ pariññaṃ paññapeti, mayampi vedanānaṃ pariññaṃ paññapema.

mn13:5.11.pli: Idha no, āvuso, ko viseso, ko adhippayāso, kiṃ nānākaraṇaṃ samaṇassa vā gotamassa amhākaṃ vā, yadidaṃ dhammadesanāya vā dhammadesanaṃ anusāsaniyā vā anusāsanin’ti.

mn13:5.12.pli: Atha kho mayaṃ, bhante, tesaṃ aññatitthiyānaṃ paribbājakānaṃ bhāsitaṃ neva abhinandimha, nappaṭikkosimha;

mn13:6.1.eng: “Mendicants, when wanderers of other religions say this, you should say to them:

mn13:6.2.pli: ‘ko panāvuso, kāmānaṃ assādo, ko ādīnavo, kiṃ nissaraṇaṃ?
mn13:6.2.eng: ‘But reverends, what’s the gratification, the drawback, and the escape when it comes to sensual pleasures?
mn13:6.2.comm: This set of three questions is a key analytical approach in the suttas. Without an appreciation of both the good and bad sides of things we cannot properly understand them and be free of craving for them.

mn13:6.3.pli: Ko rūpānaṃ assādo, ko ādīnavo, kiṃ nissaraṇaṃ?
mn13:6.3.eng: What’s the gratification, the drawback, and the escape when it comes to forms?

mn13:6.4.pli: Ko vedanānaṃ assādo, ko ādīnavo, kiṃ nissaraṇan’ti?
mn13:6.4.eng: What’s the gratification, the drawback, and the escape when it comes to feelings?’

mn13:6.5.pli: Evaṃ puṭṭhā, bhikkhave, aññatitthiyā paribbājakā na ceva sampāyissanti, uttariñca vighātaṃ āpajjissanti.
mn13:6.5.eng: Questioned like this, the wanderers of other religions would be stumped, and, in addition, would get frustrated.

mn13:6.7.eng: Because they’re out of their element.

mn13:6.8.pli: Nāhaṃ taṃ, bhikkhave, passāmi sadevake loke samārake sabrahmake sassamaṇabrāhmaṇiyā pajāya sadevamanussāya yo imesaṃ pañhānaṃ veyyākaraṇena cittaṃ ārādheyya, aññatra tathāgatena vā tathāgatasāvakena vā, ito vā pana sutvā.
mn13:6.8.eng: I don’t see anyone in this world—with its gods, Māras, and Divinities, this population with its ascetics and brahmins, its gods and humans—who could provide a satisfying answer to these questions except for the Realized One or his disciple or someone who has heard it from them.

mn13:7.1.eng: And what is the gratification of sensual pleasures?

mn13:7.2.eng: There are these five kinds of sensual stimulation.

mn13:7.4.pli: Cakkhuviññeyyā rūpā iṭṭhā kantā manāpā piyarūpā kāmūpasaṃhitā rajanīyā,
mn13:7.4.eng: Sights known by the eye, which are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing.

mn13:7.8.pli: kāyaviññeyyā phoṭṭhabbā iṭṭhā kantā manāpā piyarūpā kāmūpasaṃhitā rajanīyā—
mn13:7.8.eng: Touches known by the body, which are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing.

mn13:7.9.eng: These are the five kinds of sensual stimulation.

mn13:7.10.pli: Yaṃ kho, bhikkhave, ime pañca kāmaguṇe paṭicca uppajjati sukhaṃ somanassaṃ—ayaṃ kāmānaṃ assādo.
mn13:7.10.eng: The pleasure and happiness that arise from these five kinds of sensual stimulation: this is the gratification of sensual pleasures.

mn13:8.1.eng: And what is the drawback of sensual pleasures?

mn13:8.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, kulaputto yena sippaṭṭhānena jīvikaṃ kappeti—
mn13:8.2.eng: It’s when a gentleman earns a living by means such as

mn13:8.3.pli: yadi muddāya yadi gaṇanāya yadi saṅkhānena yadi kasiyā yadi vaṇijjāya yadi gorakkhena yadi issatthena yadi rājaporisena yadi sippaññatarena—
mn13:8.3.eng: arithmetic, accounting, calculating, farming, trade, raising cattle, archery, government service, or one of the professions.

mn13:8.4.pli: sītassa purakkhato uṇhassa purakkhato ḍaṃsamakasavātātapasarīsapasamphassehi rissamāno khuppipāsāya mīyamāno;
mn13:8.4.eng: But they must face cold and heat, being hurt by the touch of flies, mosquitoes, wind, sun, and reptiles, and risking death from hunger and thirst.

mn13:8.5.pli: ayampi, bhikkhave, kāmānaṃ ādīnavo sandiṭṭhiko, dukkhakkhandho kāmahetu kāmanidānaṃ kāmādhikaraṇaṃ kāmānameva hetu.
mn13:8.5.eng: This is a drawback of sensual pleasures apparent in the present life, a mass of suffering caused by sensual pleasures.

mn13:9.1.pli: Tassa ce, bhikkhave, kulaputtassa evaṃ uṭṭhahato ghaṭato vāyamato te bhogā nābhinipphajjanti.
mn13:9.1.eng: That gentleman might try hard, strive, and make an effort, but fail to accrue  money.

mn13:9.2.pli: So socati kilamati paridevati urattāḷiṃ kandati, sammohaṃ āpajjati:
mn13:9.2.eng: If this happens, they sorrow and wail and lament, beating their breast and falling into confusion, saying:

mn13:9.3.pli: ‘moghaṃ vata me uṭṭhānaṃ, aphalo vata me vāyāmo’ti.
mn13:9.3.eng: ‘Oh, my hard work is wasted. My efforts are fruitless!’

mn13:9.4.pli: Ayampi, bhikkhave, kāmānaṃ ādīnavo sandiṭṭhiko dukkhakkhandho kāmahetu kāmanidānaṃ kāmādhikaraṇaṃ kāmānameva hetu.
mn13:9.4.eng: This too is a drawback of sensual pleasures apparent in the present life, a mass of suffering caused by sensual pleasures.

mn13:10.1.pli: Tassa ce, bhikkhave, kulaputtassa evaṃ uṭṭhahato ghaṭato vāyamato te bhogā abhinipphajjanti.
mn13:10.1.eng: That gentleman might try hard, strive, and make an effort, and succeed in earning money.

mn13:10.2.pli: So tesaṃ bhogānaṃ ārakkhādhikaraṇaṃ dukkhaṃ domanassaṃ paṭisaṃvedeti:
mn13:10.2.eng: But they experience pain and sadness when they try to protect it, thinking:

mn13:10.3.pli: ‘kinti me bhoge neva rājāno hareyyuṃ, na corā hareyyuṃ, na aggi daheyya, na udakaṃ vaheyya, na appiyā dāyādā hareyyun’ti.
mn13:10.3.eng: ‘How can I prevent my wealth from being taken by rulers or bandits, consumed by fire, swept away by flood, or taken by unloved heirs?’

mn13:10.4.pli: Tassa evaṃ ārakkhato gopayato te bhoge rājāno vā haranti, corā vā haranti, aggi vā dahati, udakaṃ vā vahati, appiyā vā dāyādā haranti.
mn13:10.4.eng: And even though they protect it and ward it, rulers or bandits take it, or fire consumes it, or flood sweeps it away, or unloved heirs take it.

mn13:10.5.pli: So socati kilamati paridevati urattāḷiṃ kandati, sammohaṃ āpajjati:
mn13:10.5.eng: They sorrow and wail and lament, beating their breast and falling into confusion:

mn13:10.7.pli: Ayampi, bhikkhave, kāmānaṃ ādīnavo sandiṭṭhiko, dukkhakkhandho kāmahetu kāmanidānaṃ kāmādhikaraṇaṃ kāmānameva hetu.
mn13:10.7.eng: This too is a drawback of sensual pleasures apparent in the present life, a mass of suffering caused by sensual pleasures.

mn13:11.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, kāmahetu kāmanidānaṃ kāmādhikaraṇaṃ kāmānameva hetu rājānopi rājūhi vivadanti, khattiyāpi khattiyehi vivadanti, brāhmaṇāpi brāhmaṇehi vivadanti, gahapatīpi gahapatīhi vivadanti, mātāpi puttena vivadati, puttopi mātarā vivadati, pitāpi puttena vivadati, puttopi pitarā vivadati, bhātāpi bhātarā vivadati, bhātāpi bhaginiyā vivadati, bhaginīpi bhātarā vivadati, sahāyopi sahāyena vivadati.
mn13:11.1.eng: Furthermore, for the sake of sensual pleasures kings fight with kings, aristocrats fight with aristocrats, brahmins fight with brahmins, and householders fight with householders. A mother fights with her child, child with mother, father with child, and child with father. Brother fights with brother, brother with sister, sister with brother, and friend fights with friend.

mn13:11.2.pli: Te tattha kalahaviggahavivādāpannā aññamaññaṃ pāṇīhipi upakkamanti, leḍḍūhipi upakkamanti, daṇḍehipi upakkamanti, satthehipi upakkamanti.
mn13:11.2.eng: Once they’ve started quarreling, arguing, and disputing, they attack each other with fists, stones, rods, and swords,

mn13:11.3.pli: Te tattha maraṇampi nigacchanti, maraṇamattampi dukkhaṃ.
mn13:11.3.eng: resulting in death and deadly pain.

mn13:11.4.pli: Ayampi, bhikkhave, kāmānaṃ ādīnavo sandiṭṭhiko, dukkhakkhandho kāmahetu kāmanidānaṃ kāmādhikaraṇaṃ kāmānameva hetu.
mn13:11.4.eng: This too is a drawback of sensual pleasures apparent in the present life, a mass of suffering caused by sensual pleasures.

mn13:12.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, kāmahetu kāmanidānaṃ kāmādhikaraṇaṃ kāmānameva hetu asicammaṃ gahetvā, dhanukalāpaṃ sannayhitvā, ubhatobyūḷhaṃ saṅgāmaṃ pakkhandanti usūsupi khippamānesu, sattīsupi khippamānāsu, asīsupi vijjotalantesu.
mn13:12.1.eng: Furthermore, for the sake of sensual pleasures they don their sword and shield, fasten their bow and arrows, and plunge into a battle massed on both sides, with arrows and spears flying and swords flashing.

mn13:12.2.pli: Te tattha usūhipi vijjhanti, sattiyāpi vijjhanti, asināpi sīsaṃ chindanti.
mn13:12.2.eng: There they are struck with arrows and spears, and their heads are chopped off,

mn13:12.3.pli: Te tattha maraṇampi nigacchanti, maraṇamattampi dukkhaṃ.
mn13:12.3.eng: resulting in death and deadly pain.

mn13:12.4.pli: Ayampi, bhikkhave, kāmānaṃ ādīnavo sandiṭṭhiko, dukkhakkhandho kāmahetu kāmanidānaṃ kāmādhikaraṇaṃ kāmānameva hetu.
mn13:12.4.eng: This too is a drawback of sensual pleasures apparent in the present life, a mass of suffering caused by sensual pleasures.

mn13:13.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, kāmahetu kāmanidānaṃ kāmādhikaraṇaṃ kāmānameva hetu asicammaṃ gahetvā, dhanukalāpaṃ sannayhitvā, addāvalepanā upakāriyo pakkhandanti usūsupi khippamānesu, sattīsupi khippamānāsu, asīsupi vijjotalantesu.
mn13:13.1.eng: Furthermore, for the sake of sensual pleasures they don their sword and shield, fasten their bow and arrows, and charge wetly plastered bastions, with arrows and spears flying and swords flashing.
mn13:13.1.comm: Bastions were “wetly plastered” (addāvalepana) for resistance from fire (SN 35.243:7.1).

mn13:13.2.pli: Te tattha usūhipi vijjhanti, sattiyāpi vijjhanti, chakaṇakāyapi osiñcanti, abhivaggenapi omaddanti, asināpi sīsaṃ chindanti.
mn13:13.2.eng: There they are struck with arrows and spears, splashed with dung, crushed by a superior force, and their heads are chopped off,
mn13:13.2.comm: For “splashed with dung” (chakaṇakāyapi osiñcanti), PTS reads pakkaṭṭhī, but this word appears to be spurious. The commentary says chakaṇakā means “boiling cowdung”, but nothing in the word itself suggests “boiling”. The Chinese parallels at MA 99 and T 53 have “molten copper” 融銅, while EA 21.9 has “molten iron” (消鐵). | Abhivagga is only found here in Pali. The Atharvaveda (3.5.2, 6.54.2, 11.2.4) has abhīvarga apparently in the sense of “domain”. The commentary says abhivagga was a “hundred-toothed” weapon that crushed invaders of a castle. However, vagga has the recognized military sense of “cadre, company, platoon”, so I take abhivagga to mean “superior force”.

mn13:13.3.pli: Te tattha maraṇampi nigacchanti, maraṇamattampi dukkhaṃ.
mn13:13.3.eng: resulting in death and deadly pain.

mn13:13.4.pli: Ayampi, bhikkhave, kāmānaṃ ādīnavo sandiṭṭhiko, dukkhakkhandho kāmahetu kāmanidānaṃ kāmādhikaraṇaṃ kāmānameva hetu.
mn13:13.4.eng: This too is a drawback of sensual pleasures apparent in the present life, a mass of suffering caused by sensual pleasures.

mn13:14.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, kāmahetu kāmanidānaṃ kāmādhikaraṇaṃ kāmānameva hetu sandhimpi chindanti, nillopampi haranti, ekāgārikampi karonti, paripanthepi tiṭṭhanti, paradārampi gacchanti.
mn13:14.1.eng: Furthermore, for the sake of sensual pleasures they break into houses, plunder wealth, steal from isolated buildings, commit highway robbery, and commit adultery.

mn13:14.2.pli: Tamenaṃ rājāno gahetvā vividhā kammakāraṇā kārenti—
mn13:14.2.eng: The rulers would arrest them and subject them to various punishments—

mn13:14.3.pli: kasāhipi tāḷenti, vettehipi tāḷenti, aḍḍhadaṇḍakehipi tāḷenti; hatthampi chindanti, pādampi chindanti, hatthapādampi chindanti, kaṇṇampi chindanti, nāsampi chindanti, kaṇṇanāsampi chindanti; bilaṅgathālikampi karonti, saṅkhamuṇḍikampi karonti, rāhumukhampi karonti, jotimālikampi karonti, hatthapajjotikampi karonti, erakavattikampi karonti, cīrakavāsikampi karonti, eṇeyyakampi karonti, baḷisamaṃsikampi karonti, kahāpaṇikampi karonti, khārāpatacchikampi karonti, palighaparivattikampi karonti, palālapīṭhakampi karonti, tattenapi telena osiñcanti, sunakhehipi khādāpenti, jīvantampi sūle uttāsenti, asināpi sīsaṃ chindanti.
mn13:14.3.eng: whipping, caning, and clubbing; cutting off hands or feet, or both; cutting off ears or nose, or both; the ‘porridge pot’, the ‘shell-shave’, the ‘Rāhu’s mouth’, the ‘garland of fire’, the ‘burning hand’, the ‘bulrush twist’, the ‘bark dress’, the ‘antelope’, the ‘meat hook’, the ‘coins’, the ‘caustic pickle’, the ‘twisting bar’, the ‘straw mat’; being splashed with hot oil, being fed to the hounds, being impaled alive, and being beheaded.
mn13:14.3.comm: The commentary explains these punishments thus. “Porridge pot”: remove the top of the skull and drop in a hot iron ball so that the brains boil over. “Shell-shave”: grind the skull with gravel until it is smooth. “Rāhu”s mouth’: force open the mouth with a skewer, put in oil and wick, and light it so it burns like the sun swallowed by the titan Rāhu (SN 2.8). “Garland of fire”: smear the body with oil and set it alight. “Burning hand”: wrap the hand with oiled rags and set it alight. “Bulrush twist”: flay the skin from the neck down, then twist it into a band by which to hang the victim. “Bark dress”: cut the skin in strips and make it into a garment. “Antelope”: pin the bound victim to the ground and roast them alive. “Meat hook”: flay with double fish-hooks. “Coins”: slice off disks of flesh like coins. “Caustic pickle”: beat the victim, then rub the wounds with caustic solution. “Twisting bar”: pin the victim to the ground by the ears and twirl them by the feet. “Straw mat”: beat them until every bone is broken and the body becomes limp as a mattress.

mn13:14.4.pli: Te tattha maraṇampi nigacchanti, maraṇamattampi dukkhaṃ.
mn13:14.4.eng: These result in death and deadly pain.

mn13:14.5.pli: Ayampi, bhikkhave, kāmānaṃ ādīnavo sandiṭṭhiko, dukkhakkhandho kāmahetu kāmanidānaṃ kāmādhikaraṇaṃ kāmānameva hetu.
mn13:14.5.eng: This too is a drawback of sensual pleasures apparent in the present life, a mass of suffering caused by sensual pleasures.

mn13:15.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, kāmahetu kāmanidānaṃ kāmādhikaraṇaṃ kāmānameva hetu kāyena duccaritaṃ caranti, vācāya duccaritaṃ caranti, manasā duccaritaṃ caranti.
mn13:15.1.eng: Furthermore, for the sake of sensual pleasures, they conduct themselves badly by way of body, speech, and mind.

mn13:15.2.pli: Te kāyena duccaritaṃ caritvā, vācāya duccaritaṃ caritvā, manasā duccaritaṃ caritvā, kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā apāyaṃ duggatiṃ vinipātaṃ nirayaṃ upapajjanti.
mn13:15.2.eng: When their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in a place of loss, a bad place, the underworld, hell.
mn13:15.2.comm: The drawbacks are escalating, the point being that hell is worse than the punishments described above.

mn13:15.3.pli: Ayampi, bhikkhave, kāmānaṃ ādīnavo samparāyiko, dukkhakkhandho kāmahetu kāmanidānaṃ kāmādhikaraṇaṃ kāmānameva hetu.
mn13:15.3.eng: This is a drawback of sensual pleasures to do with lives to come, a mass of suffering caused by sensual pleasures.
mn13:15.3.comm: Previous drawbacks pertained to what is “apparent in this very life” (sandiṭṭhika), whereas this applies to “lives to come” (samparāyika).

mn13:16.1.eng: And what is the escape from sensual pleasures?

mn13:16.2.pli: Yo kho, bhikkhave, kāmesu chandarāgavinayo chandarāgappahānaṃ—idaṃ kāmānaṃ nissaraṇaṃ.
mn13:16.2.eng: Removing and giving up desire and greed for sensual pleasures: this is the escape from sensual pleasures.
mn13:16.2.comm: This happens with the realization of non-return.

mn13:17.1.pli: Ye hi keci, bhikkhave, samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā evaṃ kāmānaṃ assādañca assādato ādīnavañca ādīnavato nissaraṇañca nissaraṇato yathābhūtaṃ nappajānanti te vata sāmaṃ vā kāme parijānissanti, paraṃ vā tathattāya samādapessanti yathā paṭipanno kāme parijānissatīti—netaṃ ṭhānaṃ vijjati.
mn13:17.1.eng: There are ascetics and brahmins who don’t truly understand sensual pleasures’ gratification, drawback, and escape in this way for what they are. It’s impossible for them to completely understand sensual pleasures themselves, or to instruct another so that, practicing accordingly, they will completely understand sensual pleasures.

mn13:17.2.pli: Ye ca kho keci, bhikkhave, samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā evaṃ kāmānaṃ assādañca assādato ādīnavañca ādīnavato nissaraṇañca nissaraṇato yathābhūtaṃ pajānanti, te vata sāmaṃ vā kāme parijānissanti paraṃ vā tathattāya samādapessanti yathā paṭipanno kāme parijānissatīti—ṭhānametaṃ vijjati.
mn13:17.2.eng: There are ascetics and brahmins who do truly understand sensual pleasures’ gratification, drawback, and escape in this way for what they are. It is possible for them to completely understand sensual pleasures themselves, or to instruct another so that, practicing accordingly, they will completely understand sensual pleasures.

mn13:18.1.eng: And what is the gratification of forms?

mn13:18.2.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, khattiyakaññā vā brāhmaṇakaññā vā gahapatikaññā vā pannarasavassuddesikā vā soḷasavassuddesikā vā, nātidīghā nātirassā nātikisā nātithūlā nātikāḷī nāccodātā paramā sā, bhikkhave, tasmiṃ samaye subhā vaṇṇanibhāti?
mn13:18.2.eng: Suppose there was a girl of the brahmins, aristocrats, or householders in her fifteenth or sixteenth year, neither too tall nor too short, neither too thin nor too fat, neither too dark nor too fair. Is she not at the height of her beauty and prettiness?”

mn13:18.4.pli: Yaṃ kho, bhikkhave, subhaṃ vaṇṇanibhaṃ paṭicca uppajjati sukhaṃ somanassaṃ—
mn13:18.4.eng: “The pleasure and happiness that arise from this beauty and prettiness

mn13:19.1.eng: And what is the drawback of forms?

mn13:19.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, tameva bhaginiṃ passeyya aparena samayena āsītikaṃ vā nāvutikaṃ vā vassasatikaṃ vā jātiyā, jiṇṇaṃ gopānasivaṅkaṃ bhoggaṃ daṇḍaparāyanaṃ pavedhamānaṃ gacchantiṃ āturaṃ gatayobbanaṃ khaṇḍadantaṃ palitakesaṃ, vilūnaṃ khalitasiraṃ valinaṃ tilakāhatagattaṃ.
mn13:19.2.eng: Suppose that some time later you were to see that same sister—eighty, ninety, or a hundred years old—bent double, crooked, leaning on a staff, trembling as they walk, ailing, past their prime, with teeth broken, hair grey and scanty or bald, skin wrinkled, and limbs blotchy.

mn13:19.4.pli: yā purimā subhā vaṇṇanibhā sā antarahitā, ādīnavo pātubhūtoti?
mn13:19.4.eng: Has not that former beauty vanished and the drawback become clear?”

mn13:20.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, tameva bhaginiṃ passeyya ābādhikaṃ dukkhitaṃ bāḷhagilānaṃ, sake muttakarīse palipannaṃ semānaṃ, aññehi vuṭṭhāpiyamānaṃ, aññehi saṃvesiyamānaṃ.
mn13:20.1.eng: Furthermore, suppose that you were to see that same sister sick, suffering, gravely ill, collapsed in her own urine and feces, being picked up by some and put down by others.

mn13:20.3.pli: yā purimā subhā vaṇṇanibhā sā antarahitā, ādīnavo pātubhūtoti?
mn13:20.3.eng: Has not that former beauty vanished and the drawback become clear?”

mn13:20.5.eng: “This too is the drawback of forms.

mn13:21.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, tameva bhaginiṃ passeyya sarīraṃ sivathikāya chaḍḍitaṃ—
mn13:21.1.eng: Furthermore, suppose that you were to see that same sister as a corpse discarded in a charnel ground. And it had been dead for one, two, or three days, bloated, livid, and festering.
mn13:21.1.comm: As shown in MN 10:14.3, this meditation proceeds not by objectifying the other’s corpse as repulsive, but by identifying “it”—the neuter-gendered sarīra—with one’s own body.

mn13:21.2.pli: ekāhamataṃ vā dvīhamataṃ vā tīhamataṃ vā, uddhumātakaṃ vinīlakaṃ vipubbakajātaṃ.

mn13:21.4.pli: yā purimā subhā vaṇṇanibhā sā antarahitā, ādīnavo pātubhūtoti?
mn13:21.4.eng: Has not that former beauty vanished and the drawback become clear?”

mn13:21.6.eng: “This too is the drawback of forms.

mn13:22.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, tameva bhaginiṃ passeyya sarīraṃ sivathikāya chaḍḍitaṃ—
mn13:22.1.eng: Furthermore, suppose that you were to see that same sister as a corpse discarded in a charnel ground. And it was being devoured by crows, hawks, vultures, herons, dogs, tigers, leopards, jackals, and many kinds of little creatures …

mn13:22.2.pli: kākehi vā khajjamānaṃ, kulalehi vā khajjamānaṃ, gijjhehi vā khajjamānaṃ, kaṅkehi vā khajjamānaṃ, sunakhehi vā khajjamānaṃ, byagghehi vā khajjamānaṃ, dīpīhi vā khajjamānaṃ, siṅgālehi vā khajjamānaṃ, vividhehi vā pāṇakajātehi khajjamānaṃ.

mn13:22.3.pli: Taṃ kiṃ maññatha, bhikkhave, yā purimā subhā vaṇṇanibhā sā antarahitā, ādīnavo pātubhūtoti?

mn13:23-28.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, tameva bhaginiṃ passeyya sarīraṃ sivathikāya chaḍḍitaṃ—
mn13:23-28.1.eng: Furthermore, suppose that you were to see that same sister as a corpse discarded in a charnel ground.

mn13:23-28.2.pli: aṭṭhikasaṅkhalikaṃ samaṃsalohitaṃ nhārusambandhaṃ, aṭṭhikasaṅkhalikaṃ nimaṃsalohitamakkhitaṃ nhārusambandhaṃ, aṭṭhikasaṅkhalikaṃ apagatamaṃsalohitaṃ nhārusambandhaṃ, aṭṭhikāni apagatasambandhāni disāvidisāvikkhittāni—
mn13:23-28.2.eng: And it had been reduced to a skeleton with flesh and blood, held together by sinews … a skeleton rid of flesh but smeared with blood, and held together by sinews … a skeleton rid of flesh and blood, held together by sinews …

mn13:23-28.3.pli: aññena hatthaṭṭhikaṃ, aññena pādaṭṭhikaṃ, aññena gopphakaṭṭhikaṃ, aññena jaṅghaṭṭhikaṃ, aññena ūruṭṭhikaṃ, aññena kaṭiṭṭhikaṃ, aññena phāsukaṭṭhikaṃ, aññena piṭṭhiṭṭhikaṃ, aññena khandhaṭṭhikaṃ, aññena gīvaṭṭhikaṃ, aññena hanukaṭṭhikaṃ, aññena dantaṭṭhikaṃ, aññena sīsakaṭāhaṃ.
mn13:23-28.3.eng: bones rid of sinews scattered in every direction. Here a hand-bone, there a foot-bone, here an ankle bone, there a shin-bone, here a thigh-bone, there a hip-bone, here a rib-bone, there a back-bone, here an arm-bone, there a neck-bone, here a jaw-bone, there a tooth, here the skull. …

mn13:23-28.4.pli: Taṃ kiṃ maññatha, bhikkhave, yā purimā subhā vaṇṇanibhā sā antarahitā, ādīnavo pātubhūtoti?

mn13:29.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, tameva bhaginiṃ passeyya sarīraṃ sivathikāya chaḍḍitaṃ—
mn13:29.1.eng: Furthermore, suppose that you were to see that same sister as a corpse discarded in a charnel ground.

mn13:29.2.pli: aṭṭhikāni setāni saṅkhavaṇṇapaṭibhāgāni, aṭṭhikāni puñjakitāni terovassikāni, aṭṭhikāni pūtīni cuṇṇakajātāni.
mn13:29.2.eng: And it had been reduced to white bones, the color of shells … decrepit bones, heaped in a pile … bones rotted and crumbled to powder.

mn13:29.4.pli: yā purimā subhā vaṇṇanibhā sā antarahitā, ādīnavo pātubhūtoti?
mn13:29.4.eng: Has not that former beauty vanished and the drawback become clear?”

mn13:29.6.eng: “This too is the drawback of forms.

mn13:30.1.eng: And what is the escape from forms?

mn13:30.2.pli: Yo, bhikkhave, rūpesu chandarāgavinayo chandarāgappahānaṃ—idaṃ rūpānaṃ nissaraṇaṃ.
mn13:30.2.eng: Removing and giving up desire and greed for forms: this is the escape from forms.
mn13:30.2.comm: Since “forms” also includes the refined visions of meditation, the full understanding of forms only occurs with arahantship.

mn13:31.1.pli: Ye hi keci, bhikkhave, samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā evaṃ rūpānaṃ assādañca assādato ādīnavañca ādīnavato nissaraṇañca nissaraṇato yathābhūtaṃ nappajānanti te vata sāmaṃ vā rūpe parijānissanti, paraṃ vā tathattāya samādapessanti yathā paṭipanno rūpe parijānissatīti—netaṃ ṭhānaṃ vijjati.
mn13:31.1.eng: There are ascetics and brahmins who don’t truly understand forms’ gratification, drawback, and escape in this way for what they are. It’s impossible for them to completely understand forms themselves, or to instruct another so that, practicing accordingly, they will completely understand forms.

mn13:31.2.pli: Ye ca kho keci, bhikkhave, samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā evaṃ rūpānaṃ assādañca assādato ādīnavañca ādīnavato nissaraṇañca nissaraṇato yathābhūtaṃ pajānanti te vata sāmaṃ vā rūpe parijānissanti paraṃ vā tathattāya samādapessanti yathā paṭipanno rūpe parijānissatīti—ṭhānametaṃ vijjati.
mn13:31.2.eng: There are ascetics and brahmins who do truly understand forms’ gratification, drawback, and escape in this way for what they are. It is possible for them to completely understand forms themselves, or to instruct another so that, practicing accordingly, they will completely understand forms.

mn13:32.1.eng: And what is the gratification of feelings?

mn13:32.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu vivicceva kāmehi vivicca akusalehi dhammehi savitakkaṃ savicāraṃ vivekajaṃ pītisukhaṃ paṭhamaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja viharati.
mn13:32.2.eng: It’s when a mendicant, quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unskillful qualities, enters and remains in the first absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of seclusion, while placing the mind and keeping it connected.
mn13:32.2.comm: The Buddha illustrates “feelings” with the highest and most refined possible feelings, those of jhāna.

mn13:32.3.pli: Yasmiṃ samaye, bhikkhave, bhikkhu vivicceva kāmehi vivicca akusalehi dhammehi savitakkaṃ savicāraṃ vivekajaṃ pītisukhaṃ paṭhamaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja viharati, neva tasmiṃ samaye attabyābādhāyapi ceteti, na parabyābādhāyapi ceteti, na ubhayabyābādhāyapi ceteti;
mn13:32.3.eng: At that time a mendicant doesn’t intend to hurt themselves, hurt others, or hurt both;

mn13:32.4.eng: they feel only feelings that are not hurtful.

mn13:32.5.eng: Freedom from being hurt is the ultimate gratification of feelings, I say.

mn13:33-35.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, bhikkhu vitakkavicārānaṃ vūpasamā ajjhattaṃ sampasādanaṃ cetaso ekodibhāvaṃ avitakkaṃ avicāraṃ samādhijaṃ pītisukhaṃ dutiyaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja viharati …pe…
mn13:33-35.1.eng: Furthermore, a mendicant enters and remains in the second absorption …

mn13:33-35.2.pli: yasmiṃ samaye, bhikkhave, bhikkhu pītiyā ca virāgā, upekkhako ca viharati, sato ca sampajāno sukhañca kāyena paṭisaṃvedeti yaṃ taṃ ariyā ācikkhanti: ‘upekkhako satimā sukhavihārī’ti tatiyaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja viharati …pe…

mn13:33-35.3.pli: yasmiṃ samaye, bhikkhave, bhikkhu sukhassa ca pahānā dukkhassa ca pahānā pubbeva somanassadomanassānaṃ atthaṅgamā adukkhamasukhaṃ upekkhāsatipārisuddhiṃ catutthaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja viharati, neva tasmiṃ samaye attabyābādhāyapi ceteti, na parabyābādhāyapi ceteti, na ubhayabyābādhāyapi ceteti;
mn13:33-35.3.eng: fourth absorption. At that time a mendicant doesn’t intend to hurt themselves, hurt others, or hurt both;

mn13:33-35.4.eng: they feel only feelings that are not hurtful.

mn13:33-35.5.eng: Freedom from being hurt is the ultimate gratification of feelings, I say.

mn13:36.1.eng: And what is the drawback of feelings?

mn13:36.2.pli: Yaṃ, bhikkhave, vedanā aniccā dukkhā vipariṇāmadhammā—ayaṃ vedanānaṃ ādīnavo.
mn13:36.2.eng: That feelings are impermanent, suffering, and perishable: this is their drawback.
mn13:36.2.comm: This describes the stage of insight meditation. After the meditator has attained absorption, they reflect that even those sublime feelings are impermanent.

mn13:37.1.eng: And what is the escape from feelings?

mn13:37.2.pli: Yo, bhikkhave, vedanāsu chandarāgavinayo, chandarāgappahānaṃ—idaṃ vedanānaṃ nissaraṇaṃ.
mn13:37.2.eng: Removing and giving up desire and greed for feelings: this is the escape from feelings.

mn13:38.1.pli: Ye hi keci, bhikkhave, samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā evaṃ vedanānaṃ assādañca assādato ādīnavañca ādīnavato nissaraṇañca nissaraṇato yathābhūtaṃ nappajānanti, te vata sāmaṃ vā vedanaṃ parijānissanti, paraṃ vā tathattāya samādapessanti yathā paṭipanno vedanaṃ parijānissatīti—netaṃ ṭhānaṃ vijjati.
mn13:38.1.eng: There are ascetics and brahmins who don’t truly understand feelings’ gratification, drawback, and escape in this way for what they are. It’s impossible for them to completely understand feelings themselves, or to instruct another so that, practicing accordingly, they will completely understand feelings.

mn13:38.2.pli: Ye ca kho keci, bhikkhave, samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā evaṃ vedanānaṃ assādañca assādato ādīnavañca ādīnavato nissaraṇañca nissaraṇato yathābhūtaṃ pajānanti te vata sāmaṃ vā vedanaṃ parijānissanti, paraṃ vā tathattāya samādapessanti yathā paṭipanno vedanaṃ parijānissatīti—ṭhānametaṃ vijjatī”ti.
mn13:38.2.eng: There are ascetics and brahmins who do truly understand feelings’ gratification, drawback, and escape in this way for what they are. It is possible for them to completely understand feelings themselves, or to instruct another so that, practicing accordingly, they will completely understand feelings.”

mn13:38.3.eng: That is what the Buddha said.

mn13:38.4.pli: Attamanā te bhikkhū bhagavato bhāsitaṃ abhinandunti.
mn13:38.4.eng: Satisfied, the mendicants approved what the Buddha said.
